It's been said a thousand times how cute, endearing, fun, and utterly amazing this game is, but repetition doesn't make it any less true. There isn't too much I can add that hasn't been purr-sistently emphasized before. Instead, I'd like to highlight something that doesn't receive the attention it truly deserves, but fellow players would certainly agree, this game is utterly unique, and all I can say is... !!FINALLY!!

In our era where most modern games tend to fall into the same old litter box of basic categories with a different story and texture pack change, Stray is a breath of fresh catnip. With a dedicated "meow" button that serves a real purr-pose, it stands out as a unique experience, and we need more of that feline freshness in the gaming world! This game is so versatile it could fit into multiple cat-egories, making it impossible to pin down.

Pros:
    Purr-fectly unique   
    A dedicated "meow" button.

Cons:
    You're not playing it right meow.

146096212.review: This is neither a challenging game or one that will truly test your brain but it was absolutely impactful all the same. I had been told many times to give it a try because it was "not what i would expect" but i did not listen. Now that i beat it i can only say the same thing to anyone else that thought the same as me. It is a very touching story with emotions in the vein of a Pixar movie (not to the same grandeur of effect but that is the style it is chasing) that, if you let it, can open the conversation about sentience in the same way a good, deep sci fi story can. Its choice to see a world through the eyes of a cat is also something that, before i played, seemed strange but now on the other end was a masterful choice that gives the narrative a beautifully alien context. My only words of warning are this, it is DEFINITELY a short game (my game clock says 10 hours but the play through was really only about 4 and a half) so if you are someone who needs 30 hours in their game to feel worth it, this is not for you. Otherwise just prepare to enjoy and step into a deeply interesting, engaging, and eclectic world that will for sure sit in my memories for a good long while.

146094771.review:
[h1] disappointing and shallow... [/h1]

...no matter how pretty the game looks or how fun it is to play as a cat. 

And that truly is the only thing about this game that makes it stand out over other indie games (which I truly don't think it deserves.) It's very fun to play as a cat and some of the level designs are very clever, allowing you to do certain things because you're an agile little kitty. It's good stuff. But, honestly, half way through the game I forgot that I really was a cat, because you get to communicate with the other robots using your robot buddy. Other than the novelty, being a cat doesn't mean anything in this game. 

Also, the story is thin, relying on a fairly standard post-apocalyptic sci-fi narrative and world design that kind of tricked me into thinking I was loving the game at first, because it kept reminding me of other games that I really wanted to play that had more depth and a more original story.

This game suffers from making you feel like it's going to be 3-4 times the size and scope that it actually is. I think the world design and aesthetics contribute to that. It's pretty short, around 5-6 hours and not as full as it could be. It's definitely not worth $30. 

Part of the reason that the world feels small is because you don't get to know most of the characters deeply because they only say 1-2 lines total, some NPCs say the exact same thing, so it feels kind of hollow and doesn't feel like you're in a real city. Also, since you're a cat, you don't actually speak with anyone for the whole game. You play as a cat but feel like you're basically no one and there's no way to know who this cat is. Since I didn't know who I was, I didn't have any emotional connection to the one companion you're supposed to care about. It's a one-sided relationship. 

I don't hate this game. It's a fun little romp and I love being a cat. But it's a deeply forgettable game beyond that with a weak emotional core.

146092635.review:
[h1]Short, Interesting Experience[/h1]

Similar in gameplay to an old-school point and click adventure, but done in a fantastically crafted 3D world. The feline mechanics are very well done and will make you feel the highs and lows the protagonist experiences. Other notables:
[list]
[*] Being able make progress but not trigger a save is horrible; I lost 15 minutes of progress due to a "teleporting back after any jump" bug
[*] Long stealth sections (e.g. [spoiler]the factory in Midtown[/spoiler]) makes you restart from the beginning on any failure
[*] It would be nice if you could sit anytime and if sleeping saved your progress
[/list]
Unless you really love the genre or want to play as a cat, I'd wait for sale.
